Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Architectural Mechanisms for Cooperative Reliability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores hardware and software techniques, as well as programming model considerations, for enabling flexible and dynamic soft error protection. Current hardware error-tolerance mechanisms take an all-or-nothing approach: the user either prepays for worst-case error protection or relies entirely on software to tolerate errors. Neither option is desirable for many applications and usage scenarios, however. Each approach results in wasted resources and squandered performance. The goal is to enable cooperative protection schemes and maximize efficiency by blurring the lines between the hardware and software control of soft error protection. The PI will investigate techniques that allow the hardware designer, software system, and programmer to make optimal decisions for their usage model. The aim is to make error tolerance a first-class optimization option in order to allow users to "pay for the error tolerance they need, rather than overpay for what they might need". Applicable scenarios will be studied and analyzed to gauge the advantages to overall system design, effective memory capacity, and performance/power. The PI will also develop methods for the programmer to explicitly yet abstractly and intuitively express trade off between protection and hardware resources. The approach is based on a new mechanism called ``limited guaranteed precision", which allows a programmer to selectively protect costly or sensitive portions of a computation.

To achieve long-term impact, materials to train developers to realize the benefits of treating reliability as a first-class application property will be developed. The education plan revolves around course modules, problems, and demonstrations at levels ranging from popular and mini-talks suitable for high-school and middle-school, through lower and upper division undergraduate course modules, to in-depth graduate-level study. The project will also introduce students who are not computer scientists/engineers to scientific computing and systems and train them, thereby increasing US high-end computing competitiveness. The outcome of this research can impact related fields, industry, and society at large by maintaining advances in computational tools for science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:
Our research targets the need for efficient and correct execution through a whole-system approach with the work focusing primarily on resilience---the ability of a computer to operate correctly in the face of errors or failures exhibited during execution. The goal of the research is to enable strong and adaptable cooperative protection schemes and maximize efficiency by blurring the lines between decisions made by the hardware designer, software system, and programmer. Toward this goal we explored unique new computer architecture mechanisms that provide fundamentally stronger and more flexible protection against errors in failures in computer memory, provided new mechanisms and insights into how arithmetic errors should be addressed and considered by a programmer, and developed new methodologies and evaluation tools (released as open source software under a permissive BSD license).

Over the course of the project, we accomplished the vast majortiy of our goals and innovated significantly on how resilience should be considered and applied. We improved the state of the art in terms of new memory protections schemes that are flexible, adaptive, and offer better error and failure protection than all previously published and studied schemes. We introduced new ideas in how resilience can and should be adapted and developed and evaluated mechanisms that do so. We identified and studied problems related to errors in parallel architectures and proposed methods to address them, including prototyping those methods in our own silicon chips. We recognized an important problem in previous error detection schemes that target arithmetic operations, in that those schemes do not offer any numerical guarantees. We then proceeded to solve this problem with new approximate-duplication circuit designs. In order to evaluate these unique contributions, we developed new tools and methods that simultaneously both speed up evaluation campaigns and increases their fidelity and have been releasing these tools as open source software.

Broader Impacts:

Our research has had direct and indirect impact on the academic community. The techniques we developed have been widely recognized as important and innovative and have inspired a large amount of follow-on and otherwise related research. Overall, the work from this project has led to 14 scientific publications at the very top venues, which have already been cited roughly 500 times. In addition, the project partially supported the training of 8 PhD students and 1 MS student who have joined leading technology companies in the US in research roles. The project also assisted with developing educational materials that have been disseminated to the community under permissive Creative Commons license.

The impact on the broader society is important yet indirect. The results of this project will enable better, more efficient, and more scalable supercomputers and datacenters. We all rely on the scientific, medical, and pharmaceutical advances enabled by supercomputers and large datacenters are now at the center of nearly all services we rely on as individuals and society.
